Executive Summary

The Niagara County Water District Williams Road Treatment Plant provides potable water for 150,000 people in Towns and Villages located in Niagara, Erie and Orleans Counties.  The treatment plant utilizes pre-chlorination, coagulation, flocculation, sedimentation and filtration processes to ensure the quality of the water.  

Introduction
The Niagara County Water District Williams Road Treatment Plant provides potable water for 150,000 people in Towns and Villages located in Niagara, Erie and Orleans Counties.  The treatment plant utilizes pre-chlorination, coagulation, flocculation, sedimentation and filtration processes to ensure the quality of the water.  

The Facility and the Regulated Substances Handled 
The Niagara County Water District operates a 48-MGD Water Treatment Plant that uses chlorination for disinfection and zebra mussel control.  Chlorine (Cl2) is a regulated substance that is used in the water treatment process and stored at the treatment plant.  There are eight (8) one-ton tanks used for the storage of chlorine.  The maximum quantity of chlorine that can be stored at the treatment plant is therefore 16,000 pounds.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The Niagara County Water District (NCWD) periodically conducts hazard reviews to identify, evaluate and control the risk associated with the process hazards and chemical release scenarios at the NCWD Williams Road Water Treatment Plant.  The overall purpose of the hazard review is to prevent or minimize the effects of a chemical release and to comply with EPA regulations. Whenever necessary, recommendations are made during the review to reduce the risk associated with a hazard or release scenario to an acceptable level.  
At the NCWD or any other water treatment plant, well-trained operators are integral to preventing and mitigating the effects of accidental chemical releases.  The NCWD provides an employee-training program for all Cl2 operato

rs and maintenance personnel and employees participate in an annual evacuation drill.  Personnel and contractors working at the regulated facility receive emergency response awareness-level training.  In addition, selected Cl2 operators and maintenance personnel receive responder-level training.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program
The Niagara County Water District chlorine system is an EPA RMP-regulated process.
The Niagara County Water District has a mechanical integrity program.  The purpose of the mechanical integrity program is to ensure the continued integrity of the process equipment.  An effective mechanical integrity program is integral to preventing accidental chemical releases that may result from mechanical failure of improperly maintained equipment.  As a key component of the mechanical integrity program the NCWD contracts annual maintenance, testing, and inspection to Neal Systems Incorporated (NSI) so that adequate expertise is provided.  The mechanical integrity program includes the following elements:
¿	Identification of critical equipment and instrumentation.
¿	Written maintenance, testing and inspection schedules and procedures.
¿	Maintenance personnel training.
¿	Maintenance, testing, and inspection completion and documentation.
¿	Correction of equipment deficiencies.
¿	Quality assurance of new equipment.
All incidents at the NCWD Williams Road Plant which resulted in, or could have reasonably resulted in a release of chlorine, will be promptly investigated.  The purpose of the incident investigation procedure is to identify the underlying causes of an incident and to implement corrective actions to prevent the incident from reoccurring. 
Any changes performed to the chlorine system must first go through the Management of Change (MoC) procedure.  The purpose of the MoC procedure is to ensure that system changes are properly reviewed against original system design specifications and can be accomplished safely, and that system

s are ready to operate safely in accordance with original design intent following implementation of the change.

Five Year Accident History
The Niagara County Water District has had no accidental releases of chlorine in the past five years.

Emergency Response Program
The Niagara County Water District has an Emergency Response Program developed by Niagara County as part of a county wide program in place to be prepared for any accidental releases of chlorine.  The chlorine feed room is continuously monitored by chlorine gas sensors which will activate an alarm system if the ambient chlorine gas levels reach 2 ppm.  The Chief Operator and/or Supervisor of Maintenance is responsible for the overall emergency coordination.  In the absence of the Chief Operator, or Supervisor of Maintenance, the Operator in Charge shall assume emergency coordinator responsibilities.  Responsibilities include: 
a)	Notification of the Chief Operator, Administrative Director and the Supervisor of Maintenance as required.
b)	Notification of the fire department and law enforcement: 911
c)	Coordinating and cooperating with town, county state and federal emergency and regulatory agencies and officials.
d)	The following agencies must be notified when there has been a release of 10 lbs. or greater of chlorine into air or water, or 4.54 lbs. or greater of chlorine onto the land.
e)	Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) - Niagara County Hazmat Team and Niagara Falls Air Reserve Station Team
f)	New York State Emergency Response Center
g)	National Response Center
In addition the NCWD has conducted chlorine leak drills with responding parties and evacuation training with their own employees.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The most recent Process Hazard Analysis was conducted on July 14, 2021.  Process changes were made for new personnel and the addition of a chlorine scrubber to the system to improve safety.  The procedural changes were to develop a SOP for the operation of th

e chlorine scrubber and update the critical equipment. The scrubber was put into service on May 27, 2021. The construction is wrapping up and RMP will be updated as necessary with the closeout information and resubmitted to the EPA as an addendum.
